snippet: Hundreds of half-trained and well-armed members of an army for hire, now stranded in Somalia, offer a lesson in the risks of outsourced wars.
abstract: Hundreds of half-trained and well-armed members of the Puntland Maritime Police Force in Somalia have been abandoned by their sponsors and left to fend for themselves, offering a lesson in the risks of outsourced wars; members of the army, formed by private contractors to defeat pirates off the Somalia coast, could now join pirate forces or Qaeda-linked militants, or sell themselves to the highest bidder in Somalia’s clan wars.

byline.original: By MARK MAZZETTI and ERIC SCHMITT

lead_paragraph: Hundreds of half-trained and well-armed members of an army for hire, now stranded in Somalia, offer a lesson in the risks of outsourced wars.

headline.main: Private Army Formed to Fight Somali Pirates Leaves Troubled Legacy
headline.print_headline: Murky Legacy Of Army Hired To Fight Piracy
